hints.content: First, we need to find $7\dfrac12$ grams on the number line.

$7\dfrac12$ is after $7$ but before $8$.

[[☃ image 1]]

There are $2$ equal parts, or halves, between each whole. We can label each tick.

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A line plot that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7 and 8. Between the labeled tick marks is one unlabeled tick mark equally spaced between 7 and 8. !
A line plot that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7, 7 and one-half, and 8. The tick mark at 7 and one-half is highlighted. !

hints.content:
Each dot represents one strawberry. 

So, we need to count all of the dots on the line plot that represent  strawberries that weigh $7\dfrac12$ grams.  

[[☃ image 1]]

There are $\greenD2$ dots that represent strawberries that weigh $7\dfrac12$ grams.

options.alt: A line plot labeled Strawberry weights (grams) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above 7, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 7 and 8, 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9, 3 dots above 9, 2 dots above 10, 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 11 and 12, and 2 dots above 12. The unlabeled tick mark between 7 and 8 and 2 dots above it are highlighted. !

hints.content:
Next, we need to find $10\dfrac12$ grams on the number line.

$10\dfrac12$ is after $10$ but before $11$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 10, 10 and one-half, and 11. The tick mark at 10 and one-half is highlighted. !

hints.content:
Then we need to count all of the dots on the line plot that represent strawberries that weigh $10\dfrac12$ grams.

[[☃ image 1]]

There are $\purpleD5$ dots that represent strawberries that weigh $10\dfrac12$ grams.

options.alt: A line plot labeled Strawberry weights (grams) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above 7, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 7 and 8, 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9, 3 dots above 9, 2 dots above 10, 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 11 and 12, and 2 dots above 12. The 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11 are highlighted. !

hints.content: To find how many fewer, we can subtract $\purpleD5 - \greenD2 =\maroonD3$
$\maroonD3$ fewer strawberries weigh  $7\dfrac12$ grams than weighs $10\dfrac12$ grams.

question.content:
The weights of some strawberries are shown below.  

[[☃ image 1]]

**How many fewer strawberries weigh $7\dfrac12$ grams than weigh $10\dfrac12$ grams?** 
 
[[☃ input-number 1]] strawberries

options.alt: A line plot labeled Strawberry weights (grams) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above 7, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 7 and 8, 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9, 3 dots above 9, 2 dots above 10, 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 11 and 12, and 2 dots above 12. !
